article:
'Bacterial microcompartments' are widespread bacterial organelles that are made
of a protein shell that surrounds and encloses various enzymes. These compartments are typically about 100-200 nanometres
across and made of interlocking proteins. They do not contain lipids
since they are not surrounded by a membrane. Protein-enclosed compartments are
also found in eukaryotes, such as the mysterious vault complex.
headings: Protein families forming the microcompartment shell
